title: Towards Fully-Automated Materials Discovery via Large-Scale Synthesis Dataset and Expert-Level LLM-as-a-Judge
author: Heegyu Kim (Ajou University), Taeyang Jeon (Ajou University), Seungtaek Choi (Ajou University), Jihoon Hong (Ajou University), Dongwon Jeon (Ajou University), Sungbum Cho (Ajou University), Ga-Yeon Baek (Hanyang University), Kyung-Won Kwak (Hanyang University), ..., Hyunsouk Cho (Ajou University)
relevance_why: This paper introduces a framework utilizing large language models for materials synthesis evaluation, potentially enhancing the efficiency of audio-related material design processes in audio-engineering tasks.
background: The research focuses on automating materials synthesis prediction using machine learning models that evaluate synthesis procedures against expert-defined metrics, aiming to streamline the experimental design process.
contribution: This study introduces the Open Materials Guide dataset and the AlchemyBench framework to automate evaluation tasks in materials synthesis, achieving significant alignment with expert assessments.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing synthesis prediction models often lack comprehensive benchmarks and rely on limited datasets, reducing generalizability.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs a large language model as an evaluator, which significantly enhances evaluation reliability and reduces the need for costly human assessments.

key_innovation: The integration of an LLM-as-a-Judge framework offers automated, scalable evaluation of synthesis recipes, paving the way for broader adoption of AI in material design.
real_world_impact: This framework could accelerate innovation in materials science by providing researchers with reliable predictions that reduce trial-and-error experimentation, directly impacting fields such as energy storage and electronic materials.
limitations: The paper mentions biases in domain coverage and potential inaccuracies in LLM outputs affecting the performance in complex tasks.

new_terms.LLM-as-a-Judge: **LLM-as-a-Judge** refers to the use of large language models to evaluate and score predictions automatically, assessing their alignment with expert judgments without extensive human involvement.
new_terms.Retrieval-Augmented Generation: **Retrieval-Augmented Generation** is a technique that incorporates relevant information from external databases to improve the quality and context of generated outputs.

open_sourcing: The dataset and code are available as open-source resources for the research community.
